content.definition: Retrograde flow in the venous system due to failure of venous valves to maintain unidirectional flow toward the heart. Primary reflux results from intrinsic valve degeneration; secondary reflux follows valve destruction from DVT (post-thrombotic syndrome). Manifests as varicose veins, edema, skin changes, and ulceration.

pathophysiology: Valve leaflet incompetence allows retrograde flow

diagnosis.duplex_ultrasound: Gold standard - reflux >0.5 seconds after release
diagnosis.technique: Standing patient, Valsalva or cuff deflation
diagnosis.mapping: Identify incompetent segments, perforators, DVT history

ceap_correlation.C3_C4: Edema, skin changes from venous hypertension
ceap_correlation.C5_C6: Ulceration from severe chronic venous hypertension

clinical_pearls: Reflux >0.5 seconds = pathologic (>1 second in deep veins)
GSV ablation reduces reflux and heals ulcers in 60-80%
Duplex before any intervention - maps disease, excludes DVT
Perforator incompetence often overlooked - check medial calf
Deep reflux harder to treat - may need valve reconstruction
